newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: Slovakia preparing new bankruptcy law - PM.
newsitem.headline: Slovakia preparing new bankruptcy law - PM.

text.p: Slovakia is preparing new bankruptcy legislation aimed at speeding up and simplifying the process so that banks could restructure their loan portfolios, Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar said on Wednesday.

"Around 20 percent of Slovak enterprises are ripe for bankruptcy, or receivership," Meciar told a news conference after the first session of a four-day meeting of the country's economic and financial experts.
"We are planning to create mechanism for bankruptcy procedures and enable banks to move their assets into profitable capital investments," he said.
The meeting in this western Slovak spa town is billed as a no-holds-barred session that should map the country's economic plans to the year 2000.
"All opinions are allowed, there is no pulling of rank at this meeting," Meciar said in his opening speech earlier on Wednesday.
He said the government and the banking sector were also discussing ways to write off irretrievable loans.
"At the moment these loans are on the books as assets and the banks pay tax on them. We must find ways to restructure this state of affair," Meciar said.
Last year, the Slovak banking sector had classified loans of around 90 billion crowns, most of them held by the four largest financial institutions.
They are required to provision additional reserves of around 30 billion crowns to cover them.
"We're seeking an agreement on restructuring these reserves and enable them to be used for concrete investment," Meciar said.
He added several of Slovakia's smaller banks might be urged to merge to increase competition in the domestic financial market.
Slovakia was also planning to set up by the end of this year an export-import bank with two billion crowns in basic capital to support the country's foreign trade, Meciar said,

Slovakia's foreign trade balance has swung to a deficit of 31.9 billion crowns in the first seven months of the year, after a foreign trade surplus of 1.8 billion crowns posted for the entire 1995. -- Bratislava Newsroom, 42-7-210-3687
